Puppy Examples

Welcome to Puppy! This page demonstrates a few features that you might find useful while crafting your next awesome prototype.

Front Matter Headers

YAML data in the header of your content pages are exposed via the current_page variable. For instance, in this template I've defined the following:


names: ['Tito', 'Jared', 'Mike']

I can now iterate over these names using a Twig for loop over current_page.names:

  • Item # 1: Tito
  • Item # 2: Jared
  • Item # 3: Mike

Sitemap

You can access front-matter headers from all of your content pages using the `sitemap` property. Pages are indexed by filenames, so you can see the headers for this page by looking at `sitemap.examples`: 

object(4) {
  [title]=> 
  string(8) "Examples"
  [menu]=> 
  bool(false)
  [names]=> 
    object(3) {
    [0]=> 
    string(4) "Tito"
    [1]=> 
    string(5) "Jared"
    [2]=> 
    string(4) "Mike"
  }
  [path]=> 
  string(14) "/examples.html"
}

Data Fixtures

If you have lots of external data that you'd like to reuse across several templates, you can add them in the form as JSON files in the ./src/data directory. This list of Upstatement office locations is pulled from the ./src/data locations file, and exposed via the data.locations template variable:

  • Office #1: 319 A Street Boston, MA 02210
  • Office #2: 745 Atlantic Ave, Floor 3 Boston, MA 02111
  • Office #3: 133 Portland Street, 5th Floor Boston, MA 02114

Upbase

You elected to include Upbase with this project. It was installed in to the ./src/bower_components/ directory and added to your Sass load path. You can import it like this in your Sass files:


@import "upbase/scss/upbase";

Here's an Upbase-powered grid for your viewing pleasure:

1
2
3

Modernizr

You elected to include Modernizr with this project.

Puppy uses the gulp-modernizr plugin to generate a custom build of Modernizr based on feature tests you're actually using in your code.
